<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The hydrothermal reactions of 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC) and different metal ions gave rise to three coordination polymers, {[Co(bpp)(OH-BDC)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) [Ni(bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(OH-BDC)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and {[Cd(bpp)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(OH-BDC)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). The long flexible bpp ligands adopt different conformations to take part in coordination in the three compounds.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
The hydrothermal reactions of 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (OH-H2BDC) and different metal ions gave rise to three coordination polymers, {[Co(bpp)(OH-BDC)]·H2O}
n
 (1) [Ni(bpp)1.5(H2O)(OH-BDC)]
n
 (2) and {[Cd(bpp)(H2O)(OH-BDC)]·2H2O}
n
 (3). The long flexible bpp ligands adopt different conformations to take part in coordination in the three compounds.

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Three interpenetrated polymeric networks, {[Co(bpp)(OH-BDC)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) [Ni(bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(OH-BDC)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and {[Cd(bpp)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(OH-BDC)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), have been prepared by hydrothermal reactions of 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC), with Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, Ni(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, respectively. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that the three compounds all exhibit interpenetrated but entirely different structures. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a fourfold interpenetrated <ce:italic>adamantanoid</ce:italic> structure with water molecules as space fillers, in which bpp adopts a TG conformation (<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>G</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic>). Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is an interdigitated structure from the interpenetrated long arms of one-dimensional molecular ladders, while bpp in 2 adopts both TT and TG conformations. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a twofold interpenetrated three-dimensional network from a one-dimensional metal-carboxylate chain bridged by TG conformational bpp. The hydrogen bonding interactions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> further stabilize the whole structural frameworks and play critical roles in their constructions.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Three interpenetrated polymeric networks, {[Co(bpp)(OH-BDC)]·H2O}
n
 (1) [Ni(bpp)1.5(H2O)(OH-BDC)]
n
 (2) and {[Cd(bpp)(H2O)(OH-BDC)]·2H2O}
n
 (3), have been prepared by hydrothermal reactions of 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (OH-H2BDC), with Co(NO3)2
·6H2O, Ni(NO3)2
·6H2O and Cd(NO3)2
·4H2O, respectively. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that the three compounds all exhibit interpenetrated but entirely different structures. Compound 1 is a fourfold interpenetrated adamantanoid structure with water molecules as space fillers, in which bpp adopts a TG conformation (T
=
trans, G
=
gauche). Compound 2 is an interdigitated structure from the interpenetrated long arms of one-dimensional molecular ladders, while bpp in 2 adopts both TT and TG conformations. Compound 3 is a twofold interpenetrated three-dimensional network from a one-dimensional metal-carboxylate chain bridged by TG conformational bpp. The hydrogen bonding interactions in 1–3 further stabilize the whole structural frameworks and play critical roles in their constructions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The rational design and construction of coordination polymers based upon assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands is an interesting research field. This not only stems from their potential application as functional materials but also from their intriguing structural topologies . Among the various architectures, interpenetrated and intertwinded phenomena are frequently observed, especially in <ce:italic>adamantanoid</ce:italic> networks, polythreaded and interdigitated structures . In principle, the exploration of long ligands usually lead to large voids that may further result in interpenetrated or entangled structures , of which the most outstanding examples are the long dipyridyl ligands, such as 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe) and 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (dpe). Using these ligands  or their mixture with other organic ligands , many desirable interpenetrated metal-organic networks have been constructed. However, the assembly of these neutral N-donor ligands with metal ions is heavily dependent on the presence of different counterions .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
The rational design and construction of coordination polymers based upon assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands is an interesting research field. This not only stems from their potential application as functional materials but also from their intriguing structural topologies . Among the various architectures, interpenetrated and intertwinded phenomena are frequently observed, especially in adamantanoid networks, polythreaded and interdigitated structures . In principle, the exploration of long ligands usually lead to large voids that may further result in interpenetrated or entangled structures , of which the most outstanding examples are the long dipyridyl ligands, such as 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe) and 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (dpe). Using these ligands  or their mixture with other organic ligands , many desirable interpenetrated metal-organic networks have been constructed. However, the assembly of these neutral N-donor ligands with metal ions is heavily dependent on the presence of different counterions .

Accordingly, it possesses TT, TG, GG and GG′ conformations (<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>, G<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic>) owing to the free twist of the propyl group (–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–). Thereby it can adopt different conformations to take part in coordination . (2) The aim of combining OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC into the reaction system is to simplify the control and modulation of the final results, because the deprotonated carboxylate groups, which possess rich coordination modes (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig11"></ce:float-anchor>), may act as anionic groups and afford neutral metal-organic frameworks. (3) The hydroxyl group (–OH) can provide hydrogen bonding interactions with other groups and further stabilize the structures. On the other hand, the architectures from mixed ligands of bpp and di-or poly-carboxylate ligands, to our knowledge, are still rare to date , although some metal-organic frameworks from the direct assembly of bpp and metal ions have been investigated . All of the three compounds display interpenetrated structures. Exo-bidentate bpp in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> adopts a TG conformation, while bpp in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> acts as a terminal and exo-bidentate ligand with TT and TG conformations, respectively.</ce:para>

In this regard, our synthetic strategy was to select an analogue of bpe or dpe: 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp), and introduce benzenedicarboxylic acid (5-hydroxyisophthalic acid, OH-H2BDC) as an auxiliary ligand into the reaction systems, with the following considerations: (1) Bpp, compared to bpe or dpe, has a longer and more flexible conformation. Accordingly, it possesses TT, TG, GG and GG′ conformations (T
=
trans, G=
gauche) owing to the free twist of the propyl group (–CH2–CH2–CH2–). Thereby it can adopt different conformations to take part in coordination . (2) The aim of combining OH-H2BDC into the reaction system is to simplify the control and modulation of the final results, because the deprotonated carboxylate groups, which possess rich coordination modes (
), may act as anionic groups and afford neutral metal-organic frameworks. (3) The hydroxyl group (–OH) can provide hydrogen bonding interactions with other groups and further stabilize the structures. On the other hand, the architectures from mixed ligands of bpp and di-or poly-carboxylate ligands, to our knowledge, are still rare to date , although some metal-organic frameworks from the direct assembly of bpp and metal ions have been investigated . Herein, we wish to report the syntheses and characterizations of three interpenetrated coordination polymers, {[Co(bpp)(OH-BDC)]·H2O}
n
 (1), [Ni(bpp)1.5(H2O)(OH-BDC)]
n
 (2) and {[Cd(bpp)(H2O)(OH-BDC)]·2H2O}
n
 (3), assembly from bpp, OH-H2BDC with CoII, NiII and CdII ions, respectively. All of the three compounds display interpenetrated structures. Exo-bidentate bpp in 1 and 3 adopts a TG conformation, while bpp in 2 acts as a terminal and exo-bidentate ligand with TT and TG conformations, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and physical measures</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane and 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification, all the other reagents were commercially available and used as purchased. Thermal analyses were performed using a TGA/SDTA851 instrument with a heating rate of 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min in a nitrogen stream. IR spectra as KBr disks were recorded on a Magna 750 FT–IR spectrophotometer. Elementary analyses were carried out by the elementary analysis group of this institute on an Elementary Vario ELIII analyzer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Materials and physical measures
1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane and 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification, all the other reagents were commercially available and used as purchased. Thermal analyses were performed using a TGA/SDTA851 instrument with a heating rate of 15°C/min in a nitrogen stream. IR spectra as KBr disks were recorded on a Magna 750 FT–IR spectrophotometer. Elementary analyses were carried out by the elementary analysis group of this institute on an Elementary Vario ELIII analyzer.

Syntheses of the compounds
Preparation of {[Co(bpp)(OH-BDC)]·H2O}n (1)
A mixture of Co(NO3)2
·6H2O (0.058g, 0.20mmol), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (0.032g, 0.20mmol), 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (0.040g, 0.20mmol) and NaOH (0.016g, 0.40mmol) in distilled water (18mL) was sealed in a 25mL stainless reactor with a Teflon liner and heated to 165°C for 96h. After cooling to room temperature over 24h, cube-shaped red crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 41%. Elementary Anal. Calc. for C21H20CoN2O6 (455.32): C, 55.40; H, 4.43; N, 6.15. Found: C, 55.38; H, 4.51; N, 6.11%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3400 (m), 2927 (w), 1615 (s), 1575 (vs), 1401 (vs), 1373 (s), 1276 (s), 1018 (m), 785 (s), 723 (s), 519 (m).

Preparation of [Ni(bpp)1.5(H2O)(OH-BDC)]n (2)
A mixture of Ni(NO3)2
·6H2O (0.073g, 0.25mmol), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (0.045g, 0.25mmol), 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (0.050g, 0.25mmol) and NaOH (0.020g, 0.50mmol) in distilled water (18mL) was sealed in a 25mL stainless reactor with a Teflon liner and heated to 170°C for 96h. Found: C, 59.62; H, 5.02; N, 7.49%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3354 (w), 1616 (s), 1562 (vs), 1452 (s), 1412 (vs), 1357 (vs), 1277 (m), 1068 (m), 800 (s), 727 (s), 523 (m).

Preparation of {[Cd(bpp)(H2O)(OH-BDC)]·2H2O}n (3)
A mixture of Cd(NO3)2
·4H2O (0.077g, 0.25mmol), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (0.045g, 0.25mmol), 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (0.050g, 0.25mmol) and NaOH (0.020g, 0.50mmol) in distilled water (18mL) was sealed in a 25mL stainless reactor with a Teflon liner and heated to 170°C for 96h. <ce:section-title>X-ray crystallographic study</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Measurement of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was conducted on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Reflections (14<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>335) were collected at −100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, of which 4327 reflections were unique . Intensity data for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were measured on a Siemens Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at room temperature, the empirical absorption corrections were applied by using the <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps> program . The structures for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were solved by direct methods  and refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> by full-matrix least-squares using the <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>-97 program package . The positions of H atoms were generated geometrically (C–H bond fixed at 0.96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), assigned isotropic thermal parameters and allowed to ride on their parent carbon atoms before the final cycle of refinement. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the carbon atom (C15) is handled as disordered at two positions each with an occupancy of 50%. Crystal data and structure determination summaries for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>, selected bonds and angles in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic study
Measurement of 1 was conducted on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ
=0.71073Å). Reflections (14335) were collected at −100°C, of which 4327 reflections were unique . Intensity data for 2 and 3 were measured on a Siemens Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ
=0.71073Å) at room temperature, the empirical absorption corrections were applied by using the sadabs program . The structures for 1–3 were solved by direct methods  and refined on F
2 by full-matrix least-squares using the shelxl-97 program package . The positions of H atoms were generated geometrically (C–H bond fixed at 0.96Å), assigned isotropic thermal parameters and allowed to ride on their parent carbon atoms before the final cycle of refinement. For 2, the carbon atom (C15) is handled as disordered at two positions each with an occupancy of 50%. Crystal data and structure determination summaries for 1–3 are summarized in 
, selected bonds and angles in 
.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Syntheses and characterizations</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were synthesized through the hydrothermal reactions of bpp, OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC with Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> salts, respectively. Similar to the previous reports by us and some other groups, the –OH group of HO-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC is not involved in coordination to the transition metal ions and only serves as a donor for hydrogen bonds to stabilize the structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (see below), however, the –OH group as an electron-donating group may influence the self-assembly process although the reaction mechanism still remains unclear, because the expected results were not obtained when using <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-isophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC) instead of HO-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC under the same hydrothermal condition. The IR spectra of the three compounds exhibit strong characteristic vibrational bands of the carboxylate groups. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the characteristic bands of the carboxylate groups are shown at 1575<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the antisymmetric stretching band and 1401<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the symmetric stretching band. The separation (<ce:italic>Δ</ce:italic>) between <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">asym</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">sym</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) is 174<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, one antisymmetric stretching band (1562<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and two symmetric stretching bands (1412 and 1357<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) are exhibited, the <ce:italic>Δ</ce:italic> values are 150 and 205<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. For <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups are at 1564 and 1387<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, with a <ce:italic>Δ</ce:italic> value ca. 177<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The results are consistent with the different coordination modes of the carboxylate groups in the three compounds, one coordination mode in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, two coordination modes in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> () .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Syntheses and characterizations
Compounds 1–3 were synthesized through the hydrothermal reactions of bpp, OH-H2BDC with CoII, NiII and CdII salts, respectively. Similar to the previous reports by us and some other groups, the –OH group of HO-H2BDC is not involved in coordination to the transition metal ions and only serves as a donor for hydrogen bonds to stabilize the structures of 1–3 (see below), however, the –OH group as an electron-donating group may influence the self-assembly process although the reaction mechanism still remains unclear, because the expected results were not obtained when using m-isophthalic acid (H2BDC) instead of HO-H2BDC under the same hydrothermal condition. The IR spectra of the three compounds exhibit strong characteristic vibrational bands of the carboxylate groups. For 1, the characteristic bands of the carboxylate groups are shown at 1575cm−1 for the antisymmetric stretching band and 1401cm−1 for the symmetric stretching band. The separation (Δ) between ν
asym(CO2) and ν
sym(CO2) is 174cm−1. For 2, one antisymmetric stretching band (1562cm−1) and two symmetric stretching bands (1412 and 1357cm−1) are exhibited, the Δ values are 150 and 205cm−1, respectively. For 3, the typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups are at 1564 and 1387cm−1, with a Δ value ca. 177cm−1. The results are consistent with the different coordination modes of the carboxylate groups in the three compounds, one coordination mode in 1 and 3, two coordination modes in 2 () .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">To study the stability of the three compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on polycrystalline samples in nitrogen atmosphere. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the weight loss of 4.08% from 160 to 279<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is equivalent to the loss of one free water molecule per formula unit (ca. 3.96%), indicating the presence of hydrogen bonding interactions. After 317<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the decomposition of the framework starts. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the thermogravimetric analysis shows that there is no weight loss up to 360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, where the entirely decomposition of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> starts. For <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the weight loss of 6.78% (calculated: 6.61%) from 45 to 134<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules per formula unit. Complete decomposition of the framework starts after 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>

For 1, the weight loss of 4.08% from 160 to 279°C is equivalent to the loss of one free water molecule per formula unit (ca. 3.96%), indicating the presence of hydrogen bonding interactions. After 317°C, the decomposition of the framework starts. For 2, the thermogravimetric analysis shows that there is no weight loss up to 360°C, where the entirely decomposition of 2 starts. For 3, the weight loss of 6.78% (calculated: 6.61%) from 45 to 134°C, is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules per formula unit. Complete decomposition of the framework starts after 415°C.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystal structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a fourfold interpenetrated <ce:italic>adamantanoid</ce:italic> structure. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, each Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> center is in a distorted tetrahedral geometry, which is seldom displayed in cobalt-carboxylate compounds . Two nitrogen atoms from different bpp ligands and two monodentate carboxylate oxygen atoms from different OH-BDC ligands coordinate to the metal center. The average distances of Co–N and Co–O are 1.986(4) and 2.048(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. OH-BDC acts as a bis-monodentate ligand to link the Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> centers ((a)). The hydroxyl group (–OH) does not take part in coordination, but it is involved in a strong hydrogen bonding interaction with a free water molecule (O5–H⋯OW, 2.692<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), which is consistent with the result of the TGA. Bpp in a TG conformation bridges the Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> centers, the dihedral angle between the two pyridine rings is 80.6°. Thus, ten Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> centers are connected by twelve bridging ligands, namely six bpp and six OH-BDC, generating a <ce:italic>adamantanoid</ce:italic> cage, which is further extended into a three-dimensional structure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). The separations of the adjacent Co⋯Co atoms bridged by bpp and OH–BDC are 12.657 and 9.711<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The long spacers between coordination sites result in large cavities within the <ce:italic>adamantanoid</ce:italic> cages. In order to minimize the big void cavities and stabilize the framework by nature, the potential voids are effectively filled via mutual interpenetration of three independent equivalent frameworks, generating a fourfold interpenetrated <ce:italic>adamantanoid</ce:italic> architecture (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). Free water molecules are accommodated inside the framework and further shrink the void spaces. Another isomorphous complex, {[Zn(bpp)(OH-BDC)](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>, has been obtained and published by us in another report .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Crystal structure of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a polythreaded structure constructed through interpenetration of long arms of neutral one-dimensional molecular ladders. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>, each Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> center is in a highly distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Four oxygen atoms from one water molecule, one mono- and one chelating carboxylate groups of different OH-BDC ligands comprise the equatorial plane. Two nitrogen atoms from different conformational bpp ligands occupy the axial positions with the N1–Ni–N2 bond angle being 177.6(1)°. The deviation of the Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> center from the O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> equatorial mean plane of the octahedron toward the apical nitrogen atom is 0.232<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The Ni–N and Ni–O bond distances are all within the normal ranges. OH-BDC behaves as a bridge through its mono- and chelating carboxylate groups to link different metal centers ((b)). Likewise, the hydroxyl group (–OH) does not participate in coordination, it is involved in a hydrogen bonding interaction with the coordinated water molecule [OW–H⋯O5<ce:sup loc="post">i</ce:sup> 2.803<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, (i) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2]. The most interesting feature of this structure is that there are two types of conformational bpp ligands with different coordination modes . One with the two pyridyl rings being parallel adopts a TG conformation through bridging two Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> centers. The other possesses a TT conformation and serves as a terminal ligand, the dihedral angle between the two pyridyl rings is 79.6°. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>, the TG conformational bpp ligand and OH-BDC engage neighboring Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> centers into a one-dimensional neutral molecular ladder containing [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH-BDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] rectangles (14.023<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10.155<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>). The TT conformational bpp ligand behaves as a lateral arm of the ladder through its one pyridyl ring coordinating to a Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> center, which prevents the formation of an extended motif. It is noteworthy that due to the absence of large solvent or guest molecules to fill the void space in the molecular ladder during assembly process, the terminal TT conformational bpp as long arms are threaded into [Ni<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH-BDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] rectangles of an adjacent molecular ladder. Each rectangle is oppositely penetrated by two lateral arms from different molecular ladders, but there are no π⋯π interactions between the two mutual parallel and stagger pyridyl rings (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>). Such penetration not only effectively fills into the void space of the rectangles, but also results in a polythreaded polymeric structure. The hydrogen bonding interactions between coordinated water molecules and uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms of OH-BDC [OW–H⋯O3<ce:sup loc="post">ii</ce:sup> 2.589<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; symmetry code: (ii) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>] as well as the above-mentioned between the coordinated water molecules and hydroxyl groups of OH-BDC further stabilize the whole structural framework. Although some polythreaded architectures from molecular ladders with both inner rungs and lateral arms have been reported , the structural motif constructed by bpp with different conformations and a dicarboxylate ligand is still unprecedented.</ce:para>

Crystal structure of compound 2

Compound 2 is a polythreaded structure constructed through interpenetration of long arms of neutral one-dimensional molecular ladders. As shown in 
, each NiII center is in a highly distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Four oxygen atoms from one water molecule, one mono- and one chelating carboxylate groups of different OH-BDC ligands comprise the equatorial plane. Two nitrogen atoms from different conformational bpp ligands occupy the axial positions with the N1–Ni–N2 bond angle being 177.6(1)°. The deviation of the NiII center from the O4 equatorial mean plane of the octahedron toward the apical nitrogen atom is 0.232Å. The Ni–N and Ni–O bond distances are all within the normal ranges. OH-BDC behaves as a bridge through its mono- and chelating carboxylate groups to link different metal centers ((b)). Likewise, the hydroxyl group (–OH) does not participate in coordination, it is involved in a hydrogen bonding interaction with the coordinated water molecule [OW–H⋯O5i 2.803Å, (i) x
+1/2, −y
+1/2, z
+1/2]. The most interesting feature of this structure is that there are two types of conformational bpp ligands with different coordination modes . One with the two pyridyl rings being parallel adopts a TG conformation through bridging two NiII centers. The other possesses a TT conformation and serves as a terminal ligand, the dihedral angle between the two pyridyl rings is 79.6°. As shown in 
, the TG conformational bpp ligand and OH-BDC engage neighboring NiII centers into a one-dimensional neutral molecular ladder containing [Ni4(bpp)2(OH-BDC)2] rectangles (14.023×10.155Å2). The TT conformational bpp ligand behaves as a lateral arm of the ladder through its one pyridyl ring coordinating to a NiII center, which prevents the formation of an extended motif. It is noteworthy that due to the absence of large solvent or guest molecules to fill the void space in the molecular ladder during assembly process, the terminal TT conformational bpp as long arms are threaded into [Ni4(bpp)2(OH-BDC)2] rectangles of an adjacent molecular ladder. Each rectangle is oppositely penetrated by two lateral arms from different molecular ladders, but there are no π⋯π interactions between the two mutual parallel and stagger pyridyl rings (
). Such penetration not only effectively fills into the void space of the rectangles, but also results in a polythreaded polymeric structure. The hydrogen bonding interactions between coordinated water molecules and uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms of OH-BDC [OW–H⋯O3ii 2.589Å; symmetry code: (ii) x
+1, y, z] as well as the above-mentioned between the coordinated water molecules and hydroxyl groups of OH-BDC further stabilize the whole structural framework. Although some polythreaded architectures from molecular ladders with both inner rungs and lateral arms have been reported , the structural motif constructed by bpp with different conformations and a dicarboxylate ligand is still unprecedented.

<ce:section-title>Crystal structure of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is a twofold interpenetrated three-dimensional framework with free water molecules as space fillers. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor>, each Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> center is in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. Two chelating carboxylate groups from different OH-BDC ligands and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from a bpp ligand comprise the equatorial basal plane, one water molecule and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from the other bpp ligand occupy the apical sites [OW1–Cd–N1 168.5(2)°]. The Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> center is displaced about 0.221<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å from the equatorial plane towards the axial donor atom. The Cd–O and Cd–N bond distances are in the range 2.284(5)–2.614(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 2.324(6)–2.341(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. Different from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, OH-BDC acts as a chelating bis-bidentate ligand ((c)) and bridges different Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> centers to give rise to a one-dimensional metal-carboxylate chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig8"></ce:float-anchor>). Exo-bidentate bpp adopts a TG conformation with the dihedral angle between two pyridyl rings being 79.4°, which is similar to that in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Thus bpp links the adjacent one-dimensional chain into a three-dimensional framework with large channels (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cd⋯Cd distances bridged by bpp and OH-BDC are 11.967 and 10.117 Å, respectively. In order to shrink the void space and stabilize the final product, the three-dimensional network is interpenetrated into itself to generate an interwining network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig10"></ce:float-anchor>). Free water molecules are accommodated in the residual empties and further stabilize the structural framework through extensive hydrogen bonding interactions between coordinated water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms of OH-BDC [OW1–H⋯O1<ce:sup loc="post">i</ce:sup> 2.679<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, (i) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1], between coordinated water molecules and free water molecules [OW1–H⋯OW3<ce:sup loc="post">ii</ce:sup> 2.856<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, (ii) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/2], between free water molecules and carboxylate oxygen atoms of OH-BDC [OW2–H<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>⋯<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>O2<ce:sup loc="post">ii</ce:sup> 2.900<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å], between free water molecules and free water molecules [OW4–H⋯OW5 2.116<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å], as well as between hydroxyl groups of OH-BDC and free water molecules [O5–H⋯OW5 2.700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å].</ce:para>

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The hydrothermal reactions of 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC) and different metal salts produced three interpenetrated or polythreaded coordination polymers. The long flexible bpp adopts different conformations to link the metal ions. Owing to the existence of large voids from long metal–metal distances bridged by bpp and OH-BDC, all of the three compounds exhibit interpenetrated structures. This research also demonstrated that the presence of anionic groups (carboxylate groups) can simplify the design and construction of the compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
The hydrothermal reactions of 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (OH-H2BDC) and different metal salts produced three interpenetrated or polythreaded coordination polymers. The long flexible bpp adopts different conformations to link the metal ions. Owing to the existence of large voids from long metal–metal distances bridged by bpp and OH-BDC, all of the three compounds exhibit interpenetrated structures. This research also demonstrated that the presence of anionic groups (carboxylate groups) can simplify the design and construction of the compounds.
